awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Coronas, Hydrogen Oxides, and Ozone Produced in the Atmosphere by Trees under Thunderstorms and by High Voltage Electrical Power Transmission Lines
awd_abstract_narration:
This EAGER project is focused on an investigation of the potential for atmospheric corona to generate atmospheric oxidants, such as hydroxyl (OH), hydroperoxyl (HO2), and ozone (O3). Coronas occur frequently in the atmosphere near sources of enhanced electric fields, such as high voltage electrical power transmission lines (HVTLs) and thunderstorms. Trees under nearby thunderstorms are a potentially important source of coronas and thus atmospheric oxidants. Atmospheric oxidants can affect the lifetime of air pollutants and greenhouse gases, thereby influencing air quality and climate change. This research could lead to a new understanding of global atmospheric oxidation and its past and future trends.

The main questions that this research will address are: (1) How many coronas (producing OH, HO2, and O3) are generated as a thunderstorm passes over a forest? (2) How many branches on a tree and what fraction of trees in a forest under a thunderstorm produce coronas? (3) How do coronas vary on each branch with time and environmental conditions? (4) How many coronas (producing OH, HO2, and O3) are generated on high voltage transmission lines (HVTLs) of different voltages (50 kV to 500 kV typical) for different environmental conditions? 

This project meets the qualification for an EAGER award due to its nature as a high-risk, high-reward project. These will be the first measurements that define the amounts and the distributions of coronas and corona-generated OH and HO2 by HVTLs and on trees during thunderstorms. It is possible that there may be no or very little detectable coronas on trees during thunderstorms. In addition, there are several optical, mechanical, electronic, and operational design issues that must be resolved before successful measurements can be made. However, preliminary data suggest a significant probability that this research will be successful in providing key information about corona emissions related to thunderstorms and HVTLs that may lead to important new knowledge about the oxidative capacity of the atmosphere.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Corona discharges are weak electrical discharges that make large amounts of the atmosphere’s main cleanser, hydroxyl (OH). For 100 years, scientists have thought that corona must form on trees under thunderstorms because the thunderstorms’ electric fields were weaker in forests. However, corona’s weak visible glow can be seen only in total darkness. Thus, while corona on trees under thunderstorms may have been seen, the amount and behavior of these corona have never been documented.

In this study, we measured corona’s ultraviolet glow on trees under thunderstorms for the first time using a new instrument. We observed corona glow on six tree types under five different thunderstorms from Florida to Pennsylvania. Corona hopped among leaves and sometimes followed a branch as it swayed in the wind. Our observations indicate that corona glow on all trees beneath thunderstorms as they pass over forests. Besides making large amounts of hydroxyl that affects forest atmospheric chemistry, these corona can also damage leaves and affect the electric field in and above the forest.

We also measured corona glow on power lines using this new instrument. Corona were detected on power lines only when it was raining or snowing. On the insulators connecting power lines to their support poles, corona were observed even when skies were clear. The large amounts of hydroxyl made by corona can damage materials near and on these power lines.
